Title: Abhidhānaratnamālā
More facts: The first four sections (kāṇḍa) give synsets and the fifth section lists polysemes with their different meanings., This kōśa is unique in that it uses many different metres., This latter fact strengthens the identity of its author with the commentator of the Mṛtasañjīvinī., The text has commentaries by Ājaḍa and Nāgavarma II., Nāgavarma’s  Kannada lexicon Abhidhānavastukośa  derives much of its structure and content from the Abhidhānaratnamālā.

Avantivarman
More facts: Avantivarman is was a king in the line of Utpala, who overthrew the Karkotaka kings of Kashmir., He built a new capital called Avantipura, where he built temples to Vishnu and Shiva, as well as patronizing Buddhist monasteries., According to Kalhaṇa, Avantivarman’s reign was a period of relative prosperity and he supported several Sanskrit scholars and poets - Muktākaṇa, Śivasvāmin, Ratnākara, Ānandavardhana and Kallaṭa

Title: Kavirahasya
More facts: The Kavirahasya  is a versified lexicon verborum found in two recensions (274 and 299 verses)., Each stanza illustrating conjugated forms of similar verbal roots., The text uses a range of classical metres seen in Sanskrit kāvya., S.M.Tagore misidentifies the author of the Kavirahasya with   Halāyudhabhaṭṭa (of the Śāṇḍilya gotra),   a courtier of the Pāla king Lakṣmaṇasena (12th century CE).
Text reused: Dhātupāṭha ( Other (Verbs illustrated)), Mahābhāṣya ( Verbatim (the form arthāpayati))

Title: Mahimnastava
Aka: Śivamahimna-stotra, Dhūrjaṭistotram, Śivamahimnaḥ stava, Mahimnaḥ stava, Śivamahimnaḥ stotra, Mahimnaḥ stotra, Mahimnaḥ-pāra stava, Mahimnaḥ-pāra stotra, Mahimna-stava, Mahimna-stotra, Śivamahimna-stava
More facts: Often given with the ungrammatical labels Mahimnastava or Mahimnastotra, the Mahimnaḥstava [MS] is an important hymn (stotra) in praise of Śiva attributed to a certain Puṣpadanta., Written in an elegant poetic (kāvya) register, the MS hymn is a résumé of the Purāṇic Śiva as it has allusions to all his significant attributes as well as the major legends and episodes related to him., The MS is occasionally attributed to Grahila or Kumārila Bhaṭṭa., The popularity of the text is attested by the widespread distribution of manuscripts as well as the many commentaries.

Title: Mṛtasañjīvinī
More facts: The Mṛtasañjīvinī attests to Halāyudha’s skill in handling different metres, as he has composed illustrative verses that often embed the name of their metrical templum., This mudrālaṅkāra has been imitated by several later authors of texts on Sanskrit chandas., The text has verses about Rāṣṭrakūṭa Kannaradēva (named as Kṛṣṇarāja), his brother Khoṭṭiga (given as Khuḍiga ) and their Pāramāra enemy Muñja.
Text reused: Kirātārjunīya ( Verbatim (11.15)), Raghuvaṃśa ( Verbatim (1.23 , 1.61, 1.93, 1.39, 1.87, 15.61, 12.104)), Kāvyālaṃkāra ( Verbatim (KAS 3.34 kvacitkāle)), Ślokavārttika ( Verbatim (1.1)), Sūryaśataka ( Verbatim (verse1 and fragments of several others)), Meghadūta ( Verbatim (1.51)), Kumārasaṃbhava ( Verbatim (several verses from KS 1st sarga as examples of upajāti in 6th adhyāya)), Śiśupālavadha ( Verbatim (12.41, 20.79, 3.82 etc.))
Mentioned person: Kālidāsa, Bhāravi, Bhāmaha, Muñja, Khoṭṭiga, Rāṣṭrakūṭa Kṛṣṇa III, Piṅgala, Jayadeva

Title: Mukuṭatāḍitaka
More facts: The Mukuṭatāḍitaka [MT] is a lost play by Bāṇabhatta, on the theme of the duel between Duryodhana and Bhīma., Verses from the MT are found cited in Caṇḍapāla’s commentary on the Nalacampū [ca. 950 CE] and Bhoja’s magnum opus Śṛṅgāraprakāśa [ca. 1100 CE]., The play may have inspired Bhaṭṭanārāyaṇa’s play Veṇisaṁhāra, Rājaśekhara’s play Bālabhārata and Ranna’s Kannada kāvya Sāhasabhīmavijayam [c. 1000 CE].

Nyāyapariśuddhi
Scholarship: Francis X. Clooney 2001, G.Krishnacarya Svami 1940, HTR 299-305, Vadavalli Narayan 2008
More facts: Reuse of Tattvaratnākara and of Āgamaprāmāṇya, mention of Varadaviṣṇumiśra and of Prajñāparitrāṇa and Nyāyasudarśana: p. 370, śabda 1.
Structure: Adhyāyas (on the various pramāṇas, and then on the prameyas), further divided into āhnikas
Length: 508 pages in the 1867 edition (covers up to the 1st āhnika of the prameyādhyāya)
Mentions (work): Pāñcarātrarakṣā, Vedārthasaṃgraha, Nyāyasudarśana, Vedārthasaṃgraha, Śrībhāṣya, Vivaraṇa, Nyāyakusumāñjali, Bhāṣya on the Bhagavadgītā, Kāśmīrāgamaprāmāṇya, Āgamaprāmāṇya, Pāñcarātrarakṣā
Text reused: Prajñāparitrāṇa ( Other (We don't have the Prajñāparitrāṇa, hence it's hard to say whether the NP correctly attributes and quotes it.)), Tattvaratnākara ( Other (śabda, 2, p. 402. The quote is attributed, but I did not check to see whether the text is found in the TR.)), Āgamaprāmāṇya ( Other (The quote is attributed, but I did not check to see whether the text is found in the TR.)), Śrībhāṣya ( Verbatim (NP śabda, 2nd āhnika, p. 399)), Vedantadīpa ( Other (NP śabda, 2nd āhnika, p. 399. Title: Pandit Radhakrishna of Lahore
More facts: A manuscript specialist and collector., Corresponded with Gough, initiating the 1868 government program to collect and document manuscripts across all three Presidencies., His manuscript collection is no longer traceable., A handlist of his collection is mentioned as source no. 24 in volume 1 of Aufrecht's Catalogus Catalogorum, Aufrecht said that he was "famous not only for his enlightened views, but also for his great knowledge of Sanskrit lore."

Title: Viddhaśālabhañjikā
More facts: The Viddhaśālabhañjikā [VS] is a playlet (nāṭikā) in 4 acts., It describes the love of princess Mṛgāṅkāvalī, the Lāṭa princess and Kuvalayamālā, the Kuntala princess with king  Vidyadharamalla of Karpūravarṣa, and their subsequent marriage., The play was probably written in Tripuri, under the patronage of a Kalacūri king (probably  Keyuravarṣa Yuvarājadeva)., V.V.Mirashi identifies the character Virapāla in the VS with Baddiga-Amoghavarṣa III.
